Caption: Completed in 1893, the Maverick Carter House at 119 Taylor St. downtown has been owned by only two families and was home to the late San Antonio poet Aline B. Carter. After a recent restoration, the house, still owned by her descendants, has entered a new phase as an event venue.

Former Texas Poet Laureate Aline B. Carter (1892-1972) was a lifelong San Antonian who opened her home at 119 Taylor St. in downtown San Antonio to everyone interested in the arts and culture. The three-story home, still owned by her descendants, is now a cultural arts venue known as the Maverick Carter House.
Aline B. Carter in her backyard with the Municipal Auditorium in the background in the early 1930s.

The observatory atop the Maverick Carter House at 119 Taylor St. was a highlight of the Helotes Historical Society's tour of the home on Nov. 14, 2011. The house was built in 1893 by architect Alfred Giles for William Maverick, whose son later sold it to attorney Henry Champe Carter. The observatory was built in the mid-1920s. Carter’s wife, Aline Badget Carter, taught astronomy at the observatory, first to her own children, then to others through Witte Museum astronomy classes.

Greg Brockhouse has a big announcement scheduled for February 9 on the West Side at Del Bravo Record Shop, an event that the San Antonio councilman is promoting with the promise of “food, fun and music for the whole family.” Barring a late change of heart, it seems likely that Brockhouse will officially launch his much-anticipated campaign for mayor that day. It means that for only the second time in the past 20 years, a member of the San Antonio City Council will challenge a sitting mayor. Brockhouse, who often has been a divisive figure during his first council term, geared up for his campaign over the past week by recasting himself as a peacemaker: urging his obstinate allies in the fire union to negotiate with the city and praising newly appointed City Manager Erik Walsh with an enthusiasm that matches the antipathy he displayed for Walsh’s predecessor.

Caption: People accused of low-level misdemeanors appear before Travis County Justice of the Peace Precinct 5 Judge Nicholas Chu in Austin on Jan. 24, 2019. Police did not arrest them. Instead, under a cite and release program, they had been given a citation and told to appear in court within a month. With Chu are Court Clerk Maria Cristina Berrios, second from right, and Deputy Constable Kasben Harris, right. Berrios was interpreting for two Spanish-speaking defendants.

After a hearing, a defendant leaves the Travis County Justice of the Peace Precinct 5 courtroom to have his fingerprints and mug shot taken at the Blackwell-Thurmon Criminal Justice Center in Austin on Jan. 24, 2019. He had not been placed under arrest earlier. Instead, he had been issued a citation and told to appear in court, under a program known as cite and release. “Instead of wasting people’s time and wasting the county’s resources to arrest an individual, we can use those resources to focus on violent crime,” Chu said.

Travis County Justice of the Peace Precinct 5 Judge Nicholas Chu talks with people accused of low-level misdemeanors during a court hearing in Austin on Jan. 24, 2019. Sometimes, defendants are confused about the program known as cite and release, and Chu sometimes has to explain they that can’t just pay a fine and have their charge dismissed.

Travis County Justice of the Peace Precinct 5 Judge Nicholas Chu rules on misdemeanor cases in Austin on Jan. 24, 2019. With Chu are Court Clerk Maria Cristina Berrios, second from right, and Deputy Constable Kasben Harris, right. Berrios was interpreting for two Spanish-speaking defendants.

Travis County Justice of the Peace Precinct 5 Judge Nicholas Chu talks with a Spanish-speaking defendant charged with a low-level misdemeanor during a court hearing in Austin on Jan. 24, 2019. Helping with interpretation is court clerk Maria Cristina Berrios, right. Travis County was an early adopter of cite and release program, which reduces the number of people arrested for certain misdemeanors.

A program in Bexar County would treat certain low-level misdemeanors more like a traffic ticket. Under the cite-and-release program, people caught with four ounces or less of marijuana would not automatically be arrested. Instead, they would be issued a citation and could be eligible for a diversion program that would require they take a class or do community service. They could avoid having a criminal record. This photo provided by the Bexar County District Attorney’s Office shows 4.52 ounces of marijuana.

Caption: National experts and researchers from Baylor College of Medicine met at The Children’s Hospital of San Antonio on Jan. 31, 2019, to kick off a program to prevent mothers from dying during or after childbirth. Participating in an icebreaker exercise during a two-day workshop are Dr. Peter Nielsen (from left), The Children's Hospital of San Antonio maternal fetal medicine obstetrician-in-chief; Dr. Sam Bagchi, CHOSA System chief medical officer; Dr. Charles Hankins, the hospital’s president and chief medical officer; Dr. Michael Belfort of Baylor College of Medicine; and Miranda Klassen, executive director of Amniotic Fluid Embolism Foundation.

“Planet Pioneers,” a new exhibit at the Witte Museum, features interactive kiosks designed to give visitors a sense of what it takes to travel to and then survive on other planets. A crew put the finishing touches on the exhibit a few days before it was to open.

The Witte Museum
The Witte teaches kids how to live on another planet with special Spring Break explorations of its Planet Pioneers exhibit. Kids will learn fun educational lessons on sourcing food off-Earth, packing the right gear for that otherworldly trip in our solar system and other out-of-this-world survival tips, with the Space Explorers camp for ages 6-8 and the Planet Pioneers camp for ages 9-12.
Dates: March 11-15
Cost: $340/week for members or $390/week for non-members
Location: 3801 Broadway

Caption: The working poor has been given a new name: ALICE. Asset-Limited, Income-Constrained, Employed

Crystal Guevara-Alvarado, 30, makes breakfast for her four children and two nieces, including her daughter, Ellena Guevara, recently. Guevara-Alvarado was an immigration detention officer at a private center in Pearsall, Texas, for seven years and was able to help support her family by working long hours at the job. Her divorce in 2015 led to instability and pressure on her family. She quit her job in November due to the long hours and commutes taking a toll on her four children. She moved in with her sister, who offered to help.

Crystal Guevara-Alvarado, 30, serves breakfast tacos to her son, Ishmael Alvarado, 8. Guevara-Alvarado grew up in foster care and is determined to make her own children’s lives happier. She quit her job at an immigration detention center because it was putting too much stress on herself and her kids. Even with the job, she fell within the ALICE threshold — making less than what it takes to pay for basic necessities in San Antonio.

Crystal Guevara-Alvarado, 30, helps her youngest son, Joseph Sanchez, a 19-month-old, with his breakfast as he joins his stepbrothers, Ishmael Alvarado, 8, left, and Samuel Alvarado, 5. Guevara-Alvarado hopes to find new employment, perhaps with the Bexar County Sheriff’s Office, she said.

Demanding attention, Crystal Guevara-Alvarado, 30, picks up her youngest son, 19-month-old Joseph Sanchez. She said she’s fortunate to have a sister to take her and her kids in while she looks for work. She’s fortunate to get food stamps, too, she said.

“Anastasia”: A fairy tale set partly in palaces calls for grandeur, and the touring production of “Anastasia” has it in spades. Starring Lila Coogan, above, the cleverly staged production, adapted from the 1997 animated film, boasts gorgeous sets and costumes. Based on “a rumor, a legend, a mystery” about the survival of the youngest Romanov daughter, the story is compelling and often moving. And the performances are top-notch. Don’t miss it.
8 p.m. Friday, 2 and 8 p.m. Saturday, and 2 and 7:30 p.m. Sunday. Majestic Theatre, 224 E. Houston St. $40-$160, box office, ticketmaster.com. Info, majesticempire.com.
